title: IHSC Stewart 911 SENs/SIRs

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: IHSC Stewart 911 SENs/SIRs
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All Significant Event Notifications and Significant Incident Reports received by the IHSC Field Medical Coordinator or OAQ Contracting Officer pertaining to medical emergencies or 911 calls at the Stewart Detention Center for the period beginning January 1, 2024, and continuing through August 26, 2025. 

I request expedited processing of this request pursuant to 6 C.F.R. 5.5(e) and declare the following statements in support thereof to be true and correct under penalty of perjury pursuant to 28 USC 1746: 

1. The Stewart Detention Center has the highest number of deaths in ICE custody of any facility in the ICE detention since FY17. 
2. Stewart is currently one of the most populated sites of detention in the ICE system. 
3. Calls to 911 in 2025 from Stewart have exceeded their numbers for any period over the past five years. 
4. Audio recordings of Stewart 911 calls reflect instances in which EMS units were unavailable to treat significant illnesses or injuries as a result of previous calls from the facility.
5. Lack of access to timely emergency medical care threatens the health safety of people in Stewart and the surrounding community. 
6. ICE Mortality Reviewers have attributed lack of timely access to emergency medical care to a significant number of deaths in ICE custody. 
7. The records requested will shed light on whether, and to what extent, ICE is aware of the challenges posed and consequences created by its use of detention in high numbers at the Stewart facility. 
8. DHS-OIG, ICE OPR, IHSC, ICE ODO, Congress, and the General Accountability Office have all previously cited CoreCivic, ICE's Atlanta Field Office, and Stewart for violations of ICE's standards and contracts. 
9. I am a member of the media primarily engaged in information dissemination through edited publications, and have previously been granted expedited processing by federal FOIA offices on this basis. 
10. These records are needed on an expedited basis to fill out the federal side of a piece for which I have received journalism grant funding and which will be published no later than October.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Free

communications.subject: Your verification code
communications.communication: Your confirmation code is 505533

communications.subject: ICE FOIA 2025-ICFO-57001
communications.communication:
09/04/2025 

Andrew  Free 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR192063 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2025-ICFO-57001 
 
Dear Requester: 

This acknowledges receipt of your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), dated 8/27/2025, and to your request for expedited treatment. Your request was received in this office on 8/27/2025. Specifically, you requested records pertaining to ll Significant Event Notifications and Significant Incident Reports received by the IHSC Field Medical Coordinator or OAQ Contracting Officer pertaining to medical emergencies or 911 calls at the Stewart Detention Center for the period beginning January 1, 2024, and continuing through August 26, 2025. 

Your request for expedited treatment is hereby denied. 

Under the DHS FOIA regulations, expedited processing of a FOIA request is warranted if the request involves “circumstances in which the lack of expedited treatment could reasonably be expected to pose an imminent threat to the life or physical safety of an individual,” 6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(1)(i), or “an urgency to inform the public about an actual or alleged federal government activity, if made by a person primarily engaged in disseminating information,” 6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(l)(ii).  Requesters seeking expedited processing must submit a statement explaining in detail the basis for the request, and that statement must be certified by the requester to be true and correct.  6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(3). 

Your request for expedited processing is denied because you do not qualify for either category under 6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(1).  You failed to demonstrate a particular urgency to inform the public about the government activity involved in the request beyond the public’s right to know about government activity generally.  Your letter was conclusory in nature and did not present any facts to justify a grant of expedited processing under the applicable standards. 

Due to the increasing number of FOIA requests received by this office, we may encounter some delay in processing your request. Per Section 5.5(a) of the DHS FOIA regulations, 6 C.F.R. Part 5, ICE processes FOIA requests according to their order of receipt. Although ICE’s goal is to respond within 20 business days of receipt of your request, the FOIA does permit a 10- day extension of this time period. As your request seeks numerous documents that will necessitate a thorough and wide-ranging search, ICE will invoke a 10-day extension for your request, as allowed by Title 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(B). If you care to narrow the scope of your request, please contact our office. We will make every effort to comply with your request in a timely manner. 

Provisions of the FOIA allow us to recover part of the cost of complying with your request.  We shall charge you for records in accordance with the DHS Interim FOIA regulations, as they apply to media requesters.  As a media requester, you will be charged 10 cents per page for duplication; the first 100 pages are free.  We will construe the submission of your request as an agreement to pay up to $25.00. You will be contacted before any further fees are accrued. 

If you deem the decision to deny expedited treatment of your request an adverse determination, you have the right to appeal.  Should you wish to do so, you must send your appeal and a copy of this letter, within 90 days of the date of this letter following the procedures outlined in the DHS FOIA regulations at 6 C.F.R. Part 5 § 5.5(e)(2). You may submit your appeal electronically at GILDFOIAAppeals@ice.dhs.gov or via regular mail to: 

U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Office of the Principal Legal Advisor 
U.S. Department of Homeland Security 
500 12th Street,, S.W., Mail Stop 5900 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5900 

Your envelope and letter should be marked “FOIA Appeal.”  Copies of the FOIA and DHS regulations are available at www.dhs.gov/foia. 

ICE has queried the appropriate program offices within ICE for responsive records. If any responsive records are located, they will be reviewed for determination of releasability. Please be assured that one of the processors in our office will respond to your request as expeditiously as possible. We appreciate your patience as we proceed with your request. 

If you have any questions, please contact the FOIA office or Daniel Edgington, FOIA Public Liaison at 500 12th St. SW Stop 5009 Washington, DC 20536-5009 or (866) 633-1182. Additionally, you have a right to seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) which mediates disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation.  If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974.  You may contact OGIS as follows:  Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448. 

Your request has been assigned tracking number 2025-ICFO-57001. Please use this number in future correspondence. 

Sincerely, 

ICE FOIA Office 
Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Freedom of Information Act Office 
500 12th Street, S.W., Stop 5009 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5009

communications.subject: ICE FOIA Case Number 2025-ICFO-57001
communications.communication:
Andrew Free 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR192063 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2025-ICFO-57001 
 
Dear Requester: 

This letter is the final response to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), dated 8/27/2025.  You have requested records pertaining to Significant Event Notifications and Significant Incident Reports received by the IHSC Field Medical Coordinator or OAQ Contracting Officer pertaining to medical emergencies or 911 calls at the Stewart Detention Center for the period beginning January 1, 2024, and continuing through August 26, 2025. 

ICE has considered your request under both the FOIA, 5 U.S.C. § 552, and the Privacy Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552a.  Information about an individual that is maintained in a Privacy Act system of records may be accessed by that individual unless the agency has exempted the system of records from the access provisions of the Privacy Act. 

ICE has conducted a search of the ICE Office of Enforcement and Removal Operations (ERO) for records responsive to your request and no records responsive to your request were found. 

For your information, Congress excluded three discrete categories of law enforcement and national security records from the requirements of the FOIA.  See 5 U.S.C. § 552(c) (2006 & Supp. IV (2010).  This response is limited to those records that are subject to the requirements of the FOIA.  This is a standard notification that is given to all our requesters and should not be taken as an indication that excluded records do, or do not, exist. 

While an adequate search was conducted, you have the right to appeal this determination that no records exist within the above mentioned ICE office(s).  Should you wish to do so, you must send your appeal and a copy of the original response letter, within 90 days of the date of the letter following the procedures outlined in the DHS FOIA regulations at 6 C.F.R. Part 5 § 5.8.  You may submit your appeal electronically at GILDFOIAAppeals@ice.dhs.gov or via regular mail to: 

U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Office of the Principal Legal Advisor 
U.S. Department of Homeland Security 
500 12th Street, S.W., Mail Stop 5900 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5900 

Your envelope and letter should be marked “FOIA Appeal.”  Copies of the FOIA and DHS regulations are available at www.dhs.gov/foia. 

Provisions of FOIA allow DHS to charge for processing fees, up to $25, unless you seek a waiver of fees.  In this instance, because the cost is below the $25 minimum, there is no charge. 

If you have any questions please contact FOIA Public Liaison Daniel Edgington at (866) 633-1182 or 500 12th St., SW Stop 5009 Washington, DC 20536-5009 and refer to your tracking number. Additionally, you have a right to right to seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) which mediates disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation.  If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974.  You may contact OGIS as follows:  Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448. 

Sincerely, 

Megan Davis 
Deputy FOIA Officer, Operations

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #2025-ICFO-57001
communications.communication: I appeal the adequacy of the agency's search and seek expedited processing of this appeal. There is an urgent need to inform the public about the underlying causes of the hundreds of calls Stewart generated this period--calls which are rising in volume and severity. I am actively reporting on these issues and require these ICE records (or final confirmation they do not exist) to provide a full picture of ICE's response. See, e.g., https://theintercept.com/2025/12/12/stewart-911-calls-ice-ambulance-emergency/. If, in fact, the agency has no responsive records, please provide final confirmation of this so I can officially report it.

communications.subject: ICE FOIA 2026-ICAP-00094, 2025-ICFO-57001
communications.communication:
12/31/2025 

Andrew  Free 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR192063 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2026-ICAP-00094 

Dear Requester: 

The Department of Homeland Security has received your letter appealing the adverse determination of your Freedom of Information Act/Privacy Act (FOIA/PA) request by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement. Your appeal, dated 12/12/2025, was received on 12/30/2025. 

The Government Information Law Division acknowledges your appeal request of and is assigning it number 2026-ICAP-00094 for tracking purposes.  Please reference this number in any future communications about your appeal. 

A high number of FOIA/PA requests have been received by the Department.  Accordingly, we have adopted the court-sanctioned practice of generally handling backlogged appeals on a first-in, first-out basis.   While we will make every effort to process your appeal on a timely basis, there may be some delay in resolving this matter.  Should you have any questions concerning the processing of your appeal, please contact Daniel Edgington ICE FOIA Office/Public Liaison at (866) 633-1182 or at 500 12th St., SW Washington, DC 20536-5009. 

Sincerely, 
 
Sara Jazayeri 
Chief 
Government Information Law Division 
ICE Office of the Principal Legal Advisor 
U.S. Department of Homeland Security

title: Georgia Open Records Act Request – Case No. 25CV7033

communications.subject: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Georgia Open Records Act Request – Case No. 25CV7033
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

December 23, 2025

Clerk of Superior Court
Attn: Archives/Records
556 North McDonough Street 
Decatur GA, 30030

Re: Georgia Open Records Act Request – Case No. 25CV7033

Dear Open Records Officer,

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, OCGA § 50-18-70 et seq., and in accordance with Uniform Superior Court Rule 21, which governs the disclosure of records related to judicial proceedings, I respectfully request access to the following public administrative records concerning Case No. 25CV7033 in DeKalb County Superior Court::

1. Deputy Clerk Identities
Names of all deputy clerks who processed, reviewed, or rejected the filings listed in Exhibit A of the Plaintiff’s Motion for Judicial Review.

2. Digital and Administrative Records
For each filing listed in Exhibit A, I request:
Any internal audit logs, access logs, activity histories, or system-generated records maintained by the Clerk’s Office within any electronic case management, e-filing, or document management system used to receive, review, process, or store the filings, identifying all users who accessed or took administrative action on those filings.

Metadata associated with filings, including timestamps, user actions, and internal notes.

Internal clerk review annotations, comments, or correspondence associated with each filing.

Any administrative records generated in the course of processing these filings.

Copies of all filings and docket entries to ensure a complete and accurate record, including updates or amendments.

3. Administrative Policies and Training Materials
Written policies, procedures, or training materials regarding the processing, review, and handling of filings in the Superior Court Civil Division.

This request is limited to administrative records and public documentation; it does not seek confidential judicial deliberations or privileged communications. If any portion of a responsive record is claimed to be exempt from disclosure, please produce the non-exempt portions with redactions as permitted by law and identify the specific statutory basis for each redaction or withholding, as required by O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(d).”

The purpose of this request is to identify the appropriate individuals responsible for processing these filings and to obtain a complete administrative and digital record(s). This request applies to any electronic system or database used by the Clerk’s Office to receive, process, review, manage, or store filings for this case, regardless of vendor or system name.

If any fees are associated with producing these records, please notify me prior to processing. I request that the records be provided in electronic format, if available.
Thank you for your attention to this request. 

Sincerely,
/s/ Charles Stanley DeLozier Jr.,  pro se

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Charles Stanley DeLozier Jr.

communications.subject: RE: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Georgia Open Records Act Request – Case No. 25CV7033
communications.communication:

I wanted to follow up on the following Georgia Open Records Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on Dec. 23, 2025. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: FW: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Georgia Open Records Act Request – Case No. 25CV7033
communications.communication:
Good Afternoon Mr. DeLozier:

Thank you for your email. This email responds to your Georgia Open Records Act request received by our office on December 23, 2025. Please note the response to your requested documents listed beneath the request in bold:

1. Deputy Clerk Identities
Names of all deputy clerks who processed, reviewed, or rejected the filings listed in Exhibit A of the Plaintiff’s Motion for Judicial Review.

Please see the attached document.

2. Digital and Administrative Records
For each filing listed in Exhibit A, I request:
Any internal audit logs, access logs, activity histories, or system-generated records maintained by the Clerk’s Office within any electronic case management, e-filing, or document management system used to receive, review, process, or store the filings, identifying all users who accessed or took administrative action on those filings.

Metadata associated with filings, including timestamps, user actions, and internal notes.

Internal clerk review annotations, comments, or correspondence associated with each filing.

Any administrative records generated in the course of processing these filings.

Copies of all filings and docket entries to ensure a complete and accurate record, including updates or amendments.

Please clarify what documents you are referencing in Exhibit.

3. Administrative Policies and Training Materials
Written policies, procedures, or training materials regarding the processing, review, and handling of filings in the Superior Court Civil Division.
Please see the attached Civil Division Manual.

Please let me know if you have any questions related to your request. Finally, I attempted to contact you at the number listed on one of your pleadings.  I received a message that it was not a working number.

title: Weymouth Wednesdays

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Weymouth Wednesdays
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Subject: FOIA Request for Information Regarding Traffic Enforcement Policies

 I am writing to request information under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) related to the traffic enforcement policies of Weymouth Police Department.  Specifically, I seek documentation regarding the recent directive that instructs officers and command staff to conduct traffic enforcement exclusively on Wednesdays.

To assist in the processing of this request, please provide:

1. Any memos, emails, or internal communications from agency leadership discussing or promoting the strategy to issue tickets solely on Wednesdays.

2. Statistical data or reports that outline traffic enforcement activities, including the number of tickets issued on Wednesdays compared to other days of the week.

3. Any relevant guidelines or policies that mandate or suggest certain days for traffic enforcement over others.

4. Information on the objectives behind this strategy and whether any analysis was conducted before its implementation.

I propose a fee waiver for this request based on the public interest in transparency around law enforcement practices. This information is crucial for understanding how these policies may impact public safety and the fair application of traffic laws.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt response.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

TransparentPolicing2026

title: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Forsyth County Sheriff's Office)

communications.subject: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Forsyth County Sheriff's Office)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Use of force (UOF) data dating from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2025. If possible, please provide this data in database or spreadsheet format and include the case number, incident date, incident time, subject injured indicator, subject injury force related info (e.g. Yes or No), subject age, subject gender, subject ethnicity, subject weapon type, incident area occurred, force type, officer division (e.g. law enforcement operations, detention/correctional operations, etc.), badge number and names associated with the officers involved. If one or more of these fields or dates is unavailable, provide all fields and/or information that is available responsive to my request. If no database or spreadsheet format is available, please provide copies of each individual use of force report or other report where use of force information is documented/reported by officers. Note, this is for all use of force incidents reported by your agency, not limited to only those incidents required to be reported under state or federal programs.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Samuel Sinyangwe

communications.subject: Forsyth County Sheriff's Office - Record Request 2026-871
communications.communication:
Dear Requester, 
  
 Thank you for submitting a request for records.

Your request security key is 67930485.
Your request reference number is Request Number: 2026-871.

Please have this security key and reference number available when communicating with our staff regarding your request. 
  
 Open Records Requests: 
  
 The Open Records Unit will provide information relating to the request, as permissible and applicable by law, within 3 business days after it has been received. If production of requested documents is not possible within that timeframe, the Open Records Unit will issue correspondence with an explanation. If your request is denied in whole or in part, the legal basis for denial will be cited in the response. If production of the requested documents exceeds a fee above $25.00, the requester will be contacted with a pre-retrieval cost estimate prior to fulfilling the request. 
  
 Associated Charges: 
  
 The first 15 minutes of any response are provided at no cost.  Staff time to comply with request will be billed as follows: 
  
 Balance of first hour $15.41 
 Additional hours $20.54 each 
  
 Production Fees: 
  
 Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(c)(1)...the charge for the search, retrieval, or redaction of records shall not exceed the prorated hourly salary of the lowest paid full-time employee who, in the reasonable discretion of the custodian of the records, has the necessary skill and training to perform the request; provided, however, that no charge shall be made for the first quarter hour. Other fees: 
 Copies 10¢ per letter or legal-size page 
 Copies non-standard size actual cost 
 Off-site retrieval actual cost (off site retrieval could take up to 10 days) 
 Electronic media actual cost 
 Other specialized records actual cost - as provided by law. 
 Certified copies - as provided by law. 
  
 Once your response is completed, you will receive directions to pay any charges to release the records.  
  
  *Forsyth County residents whose name appear on the records will receive one copy of their accident or incident report at no cost.* 
  
 In accordance with OCGA 50-18-72 Records requests and responses may be subject to disclosure under the State Open Records Act. 
  
 Thank you, 
  
 Forsyth County Sheriff's Office
100 East Courthouse Square
Cumming, GA 30040
770-781-2222

Most of these documents should fall between July 1991 through June 1993. There may be some appeals from 1993 until 2018 which I would also be interested in requesting.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

title: Police Information Sharing Policies with Immigration Authorities

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Police Information Sharing Policies with Immigration Authorities
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records: 

1. All departmental or municipal policies regarding communication and information sharing between departmental officers or employees and federal agents/agencies within the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) or the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS), including but not limited to the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE). The records request includes, but is not limited to, policies regarding: 

A. Fingerprint and other data sharing, 

B. ICE detainer requests,   

C. Compliance with federal immigration enforcement efforts, including guidance or policies around when communication with ICE officers is allowed, and 

D. Communicating with federal immigration enforcement officers. 

This request covers any policies that are currently in effect or that have been in effect at any point on or after January 20, 2025. 

2. The three most recent communications (e.g., emails, text messages, call logs or transcripts, or otherwise) between a departmental officer or employee and a federal DHS or ICE employee. In addition, I request all records related to these communications, including, but not limited to, any records indicating that the department was made aware of the communications, discussions of their content or implications, evaluations them for compliance with departmental or other city policies, identification or acknowledgement of any potential policy violations, and any internal responses, disciplinary actions, or follow-up measures resulting from these communications. 

3. All records relating to incidents, if any, from January 20, 2025, to the day this request is responded to, in which an individual was taken from the department’s custody directly into ICE custody. For each incident, the records request includes, but is not limited to, booking and transfer records, communications with ICE or other federal agencies, internal documentation or discussion of the transfer, and internal notes, memos, or documentation referencing communication with DHS or ICE.

For each request, I am not seeking identifying information, and I will accept anonymized or redacted data as necessary to protect identities. 

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest. I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Joshua Dankoff 

Joshuadankoff@cfjj.org  

Director of Strategic Initiatives 

Citizens for Juvenile Justice  

(submitted via MuckRock platform)

the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE). The records request
includes, but is not limited to, policies regarding:

A. Fingerprint and other data sharing,

B. ICE detainer requests,

C. Compliance with federal immigration enforcement efforts, including
guidance or policies around when communication with ICE officers is
allowed, and

D. Communicating with federal immigration enforcement officers.

This request covers any policies that are currently in effect or that have
been in effect at any point on or after January 20, 2025.  See attached
policy

2. The three most recent communications (e.g., emails, text messages, call
logs or transcripts, or otherwise) between a departmental officer or
employee and a federal DHS or ICE employee. In addition, I request all
records related to these communications, including, but not limited to, any
records indicating that the department was made aware of the
communications, discussions of their content or implications, evaluations
them for compliance with departmental or other city policies,
identification or acknowledgement of any potential policy violations, and
any internal responses, disciplinary actions, or follow-up measures
resulting from these communications.  There are no records from this
request.

3. All records relating to incidents, if any, from January 20, 2025, to the
day this request is responded to, in which an individual was taken from the
department’s custody directly into ICE custody. For each incident, the
records request includes, but is not limited to, booking and transfer
records, communications with ICE or other federal agencies, internal
documentation or discussion of the transfer, and internal notes, memos, or
documentation referencing communication with DHS or ICE.  There are no
records from this request.



For each request, I am not seeking identifying information, and I will
accept anonymized or redacted data as necessary to protect identities.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this
request is in the public interest. I expect the request to be filled in an
accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide
text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not
accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well
as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform
me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer
the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available.

*Respectfully,*

*Kimberly Ottomaniello *
*Administrative Assistant/ Records *
*413-538-8231 X 6307 Phone*
*413-538-5196 Fax *

title: ADMINISTRATIVE RESPONSE RECORDS Title: Administrative Response Records - Wallingford Public Schools

communications.subject: Connecticut Freedom of Information Act Request: ADMINISTRATIVE RESPONSE RECORDS Title: Administrative Response Records - Wallingford Public Schools
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act (C.G.S. § 1-200 et seq.), I respectfully request access to the following public records:

PRIMARY RECORDS REQUESTED:
- All communications and documentation related to Policy 1312 grievance procedures from July 1, 2025 to present
- All communications between Principal Robert Arceiro and Superintendent Danielle Bellizzi regarding the Conrad family from January 1, 2023 to present
- All documentation of any conflict of interest determinations, discussions, or evaluations involving school employees and external parties from January 1, 2024 to present
- Training records for all staff regarding professional boundaries, workplace conduct policies, and custody dispute protocols

COMPREHENSIVE DISCLOSURE REQUIREMENTS:
This request includes, but is not limited to:
- All responsive records regardless of format (paper, electronic, audio, video, social media, messaging apps)
- Records stored on personal devices if used for official business
- Records in possession of contractors, consultants, or third parties acting on behalf of the agency
- Draft documents, notes, calendars, and informal communications
- Records that have been deleted but remain recoverable
- Metadata and audit logs associated with electronic records

SEARCH REQUIREMENTS:
- Search all relevant custodians, not just those specifically named
- Search all email accounts, shared drives, and backup systems
- Include records of employees no longer with the agency
- Search alternative spellings, nicknames, and partial names

PRODUCTION STANDARDS:
- Provide records in native electronic format when possible
- Do not convert searchable documents to non-searchable formats
- Preserve all metadata including timestamps and sender/recipient information
- Provide a privilege log for any claimed exemptions

If any responsive records have been destroyed, please provide:
- Documentation of the destruction
- Reason for destruction
- Date of destruction
- Authority for destruction

If you claim any exemption under the Freedom of Information Act, please:
- Identify the specific statutory exemption
- Explain how the exemption applies to each document
- Provide redacted copies where partial disclosure is possible
- Consider whether public interest outweighs any claimed exemption

This request seeks records that serve the public interest in government transparency and accountability. Please construe all exemptions narrowly and err on the side of disclosure.

Please preserve all potentially responsive records immediately upon receipt of this request to prevent spoliation.

As these records serve significant public interest, please waive all fees. If fees cannot be waived, please provide detailed cost estimate before proceeding.

Thank you for your assistance.

I also request that, if possible and pursuant to Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-212(d), fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest and not made for commercial gain. The requested documents will be made available to the public at MuckRock.com.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 4 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

john Conrad

title: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Bastrop County Sheriff)

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Bastrop County Sheriff)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Use of force (UOF) data dating from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2025. If possible, please provide this data in database or spreadsheet format and include the case number, incident date, incident time, subject injured indicator, subject injury force related info (e.g. Yes or No), subject age, subject gender, subject ethnicity, subject weapon type, incident area occurred, force type, officer division (e.g. law enforcement operations, detention/correctional operations, etc.), badge number and names associated with the officers involved. If one or more of these fields or dates is unavailable, provide all fields and/or information that is available responsive to my request. If no database or spreadsheet format is available, please provide copies of each individual use of force report or other report where use of force information is documented/reported by officers. Note, this is for all use of force incidents reported by your agency, not limited to only those incidents required to be reported under state or federal programs.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Samuel Sinyangwe

- Records that have been deleted but remain recoverable
- Metadata and audit logs associated with electronic records

SEARCH REQUIREMENTS:
- Search all relevant custodians, not just those specifically named
- Search all email accounts, shared drives, and backup systems
- Include records of employees no longer with the agency
- Search alternative spellings, nicknames, and partial names

PRODUCTION STANDARDS:
- Provide records in native electronic format when possible
- Do not convert searchable documents to non-searchable formats
- Preserve all metadata including timestamps and sender/recipient information
- Provide a privilege log for any claimed exemptions

If any responsive records have been destroyed, please provide:
- Documentation of the destruction
- Reason for destruction
- Date of destruction
- Authority for destruction

If you claim any exemption under the Freedom of Information Act, please:
- Identify the specific statutory exemption
- Explain how the exemption applies to each document
- Provide redacted copies where partial disclosure is possible
- Consider whether public interest outweighs any claimed exemption

This request seeks records that serve the public interest in government transparency and accountability. Please construe all exemptions narrowly and err on the side of disclosure.

Please preserve all potentially responsive records immediately upon receipt of this request to prevent spoliation.

As these records serve significant public interest, please waive all fees. If fees cannot be waived, please provide detailed cost estimate before proceeding.

Thank you for your assistance.

I also request that, if possible and pursuant to Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-212(d), fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest and not made for commercial gain. The requested documents will be made available to the public at MuckRock.com.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 4 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

john Conrad

communications.subject: Connecticut Freedom of Information Act Request: Food service Inspecions for Class IV licenses Danbury, CT
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am in receipt of your departments FOI request for Food Service License Renewals for 2025-2026. I find it very concerning that several Class IV Establishments have yet to be renewed over 6 months after prior permit expired. One of  which is a daycare that services a vulnerable population. 
Public Health Code Regulations have an inspection interval requirement.

Please furnish copies of DPH required inspections for the following Establishments for calendar years 2024, 2025, and 2026 until the receipt of this request.

FSE-22-151	5/14/2025 18:34	Active	Sushi Do Danbury Hospital	                        Class IV
FSE-22-5	6/11/2025 14:37	Active	Cedar Gables Preschool & Childcare	Class IV
FSE-23-33	6/19/2025 22:51	Active	Bambu	                                                                Class IV

Please provide explanation if no inspections have been conducted.

I also request that, if possible and pursuant to Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-212(d), fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest and not made for commercial gain. The requested documents will be made available to the public at MuckRock.com.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 4 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kevin Paige

title: DHS-OIG Working Papers OIG-22-47

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: DHS-OIG Working Papers OIG-22-47
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Description of Records Sought (pursuant to 6 C.F.R. 5.3b)
All working papers, interview notes, correspondence, and other agency records DHS-OIG created, received, or maintained in preparing the June 30, 2022, report to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) Acting Director Tae Johnson regarding the Folkston ICE Processing Center and Folkston Annex in Georgia, operated by The GEO Group, Inc. A copy of that report is available here: https://www.oig.dhs.gov/sites/default/files/assets/2022-07/OIG-22-47-July22.pdf. 

Likely Custodians: 
The following DHS-OIG Custodians are believed to have responsive documents and should be tasked: 
James Cuffari, Ph.D., John D. Shiffer, Chief Inspector; Stephanie Christian, Supervisory Lead Inspector Ian Stumpf, Senior Inspector; Erika Algeo, Inspector; Brett Cheney, Inspector; Lisa Knight, Communications Analyst; Lorraine Eide, Independent Referencer.

Proposed Temporal Period: 
The following time period should be searched: 
October 1, 2021 - Present (i.e., the date on which DHS-OIG FOIA tasks an adequate search for responsive records). 
We are willing to negotiate a narrower temporal period upon a representation from DHS-OIG that responsive records are unlikely to exist in all or part of the temporal scope we have requested. 

Likely Systems of Records: 
DHS-OIG should query any email systems the Likely Custodians use, as well as the government-issued phones these custodians use. 
DHS-OIG should query any SharePoint or similar drive containing records regarding the Folkston Inspection conducted in November 2021. 
DHS-OIG should query the JICMS for any responsive records as described above. 

Expedited Processing Request (pursuant to 6 C.F.R. 5.5(e)
On behalf of the Al Otro Lado #DetentionKills Transparency Initiative, we respectfully request expedited processing. 

Expedited processing is warranted under 6 C.F.R. 5.5(e)(1)(i) - Harm to individuals from delayed production. DHS-OIG concluded in its publicly available report.  

“Folkston did not meet standards for facility conditions, medical care, grievances, segregation, staff-detainee communications, and handling of detainee property. We identified violations that compromised the health, safety, and rights of detainees. Folkston facilities were unsanitary and dilapidated, with torn mattresses, water leaks and standing water, mold growth and water damage, rundown showers, mold and debris in the ventilation system, insect infestations, lack of access to hot showers, inoperable toilets, an inoperable thermometer display on a kitchen freezer, and an absence of hot meals. Facility medical staff did not provide timely access to specialty care or adequate mental health care for detainees. Folkston did not provide timely or complete responses to detainee grievances and requests. Folkston also did not consistently provide required services to detainees in segregation and inappropriately handcuffed detainees. Further, ICE did not consistently respond to detainee requests in a timely manner and did not provide detainees with paper grievance forms and submission boxes as required. ICE also did not provide detainees sufficient contact with deportation officers. Lastly, the facility has improperly handled detainee property. In addition, Folkston has not met staffing levels required by the contract with ICE to ensure proper detainee oversight. In addressing COVID-19, Folkston did not consistently enforce use of masks and social distancing. In April 2021, Folkston began providing COVID-19 vaccinations to detainees.”

On May 25, 2022, ICE responded to OIG’s 13 recommendations, purportedly providing “corroboration” that Folkston had been brought into compliance. ICE followed up on June 13, 2022, seeking OIG close its recommendations. OIG treated 12 of 13 recommendations as satisfied and closed them. However, it is unclear how or why OIG concluded it could rely upon the representations of ICE regarding how it had addressed each recommendation, such that the people locked inside Folkston experience a material change in their daily conditions. In several instances, ICE disputed OIG’s findings, even while indicating it would “concur” with the recommendations that it make changes to implement standards compliance. (See pages 39-42 of Report No. 22-47.

Expedited processing is warranted under 6 C.F.R. 5.5(e)(1)(iii) — Loss of Substantial Due Process Rights to people inside Folkston from delayed production.

Even after ICE represented to DHS-OIG that it had corrected many the violations it admits OIG documented during the unannounced inspection, detained people inside Folkston reported to DHS many of the very same violations OIG described. According to multiple detained individuals, these conditions unabated.
See, e.g., https://www.albanyherald.com/news/protests-at-ice-detention-center-mount-as-expansion-plans-move-forward/article_6c8cf39c-c25c-11ec-be63-8bbf37990359.html. 

An active hunger strike remains ongoing at Folkston to protest these conditions. 

In the past, ICE officials have attempted to deny the very conditions OIG found in its unannounced inspections during the agency’s communications with House Appropriations Homeland Chair Lucille Roybal-Allard, according to FOIA records obtained from ICE: https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/6705734-ICE-Emails-Pertaining-to-Congressional-Inquiries.html. 

Expedited processing is warranted under 6 C.F.R. 5.5(e)(1)(iv) — A matter of widespread and exceptional media interest in which there exist possible questions about the government's integrity which affect public confidence.

The future of ICE detention in Georgia and ICE’s use of private immigration detention contractors like The GEO Group is a matter of widespread and exceptional media interest on  which there exist possible questions about the government’s integrity which affect public confidence, and these records requests are directly responsive to this media interest. Accordingly, Expedited Processing is warranted under Section 5.5(e)(1)(iv). 

President Joe Biden told organizers at a Georgia car rally who interrupted his event to demand he keep his promise to close private prisons and immigration detention centers, “Give me Five Days, Man.” https://www.newsweek.com/joe-biden-says-give-me-five-days-hecklers-calling-closure-detention-centers-1587639. As the video makes clear, the President of the United States was referring to privately operated immigration detention centers, as well as private prisons. See also: https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/biden-georgia-rally-speech-protest-b1839959.html; https://www.realclearpolitics.com/video/2021/04/30/biden_to_protesters_give_me_another_five_days_to_fix_immigration.html; https://nypost.com/2021/04/29/biden-heckled-by-abolish-ice-protesters-teases-action-in-5-days/. 

Instead of ending private prisons in Georgia May 2021, President Biden ordered the termination of ICE’s contract with the Irwin County Detention Center. By December 2021, however, it became clear that far from fulfilling his stated promise, the Biden Administration would actually expand its use of private immigration detention in Georgia: https://www.advancingjustice-atlanta.org/news/closefolkston. https://creativeloafing.com/content-500557-news-brief-private-prison-undergoing-expansion-while-under. 

Then, in February 2022, the Atlanta Journal Constitution reported exclusively that the Biden Administration planned an unprecedented expansion of Folkston that would make it the largest ICE facility east of the Mississippi. https://www.ajc.com/news/exclusive-south-georgia-immigration-detention-complex-aims-to-expand/QN5G2BFOPREQHEBDOPPAX2PSVI/. 

In apparent violation of the Homeland Security Acquisition Regulations and Federal Acquisition regulations, this historic expansion would occur through a no-bid, single-vendor contract expansion. The beneficiary: The GEO Group. People supporting those locked inside Folkston protested: https://www.splcenter.org/presscenter/splc-planned-expansion-private-ice-detention-center-georgia-betrayal-biden. 

A people’s movement seeking depopulation of the Folkston facility by ICE and cancellation of the Folkston Contract has been active since 2022. http://www.charltoncountyherald.com/news/second-rally-held-at-the-folkston-ice-processing-center/article_7254cb22-bfe3-11ec-8548-978ce9320949.html.  

The timing of DHS-OIG and ICE’s responses to the findings of the November 2021 unannounced inspection raise significant questions about the Biden-Harris Administration’s planned expansion of Folkston. At the exact time OIG was informing ICE Folkston was serially non-compliant (OIG No. 22-47 contains perhaps more documented violations of ICE standards than any other DHS-OIG inspection of an ICE facility in history), ICE was planning to reward the contract with an additional expansion. At the exact same time OIG was informing ICE that its contractors had failed to follow through on the financial penalties against GEO that would have followed from the 2019 and 2020 contract discrepancy reports ICE issued, ICE was planning to further reward the non compliant contractor with a no-bid, multi year, multimillion dollar expansion. 

Why did OIG wait and negotiate with ICE, given the violations it documented, rather than issuing a Management Alert, as it did in Torrance, NM? 

What “corroboration” did ICE provide OIG? 

Why, given the serial failures of ICE to accurately document the violations OIG found on unannounced inspection, did OIG take ICE at its word and not conduct a second unannounced inspection before closing out its recommendations? 

Why do people inside Folkston still report the same violations OIG documented if OIG has concluded ICE remedied the violations? 

The records requested carry the potential to answer these questions and more. The answers are required now — BEFORE ICE signs a multimillion dollar expansion of a facility that less than 8 months ago failed an unannounced inspection. Failure to grant expedited processing will deprive the public, people inside and those working with Congress and the agency of the public records necessary to corroborate or disprove the current allegations that Folkston is not fit for human occupancy, and is incapable of reform. 

Finally, it appears that despite knowing of OIG’s findings, executives from The GEO Group made affirmative statements during shareholder calls and in public SEC filings that are contradicted by ICE’s concurrence with those findings. Because GEO’s market capitalization of $1.9bn is based nearly exclusively on its ability to obtain and maintain contracts with government partners — including the ~25-35% of its revenue ICE payments represent — the investing public has an urgent need to know whether GEO’s executives misled shareholders and the SEC regarding the services the company renders at Folkston, and its relationship with ICE as a contracting partner. 

I certify that the above statements are true and correct pursuant to 6 C.F.R. 5.5(e)(3). 

Requestor: 
Al Otro Lado and its #DetentionKills Transparency Initiative

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Free

title: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Hall County Sheriff)

communications.subject: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Hall County Sheriff)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Use of force (UOF) data dating from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2025. If possible, please provide this data in database or spreadsheet format and include the case number, incident date, incident time, subject injured indicator, subject injury force related info (e.g. Yes or No), subject age, subject gender, subject ethnicity, subject weapon type, incident area occurred, force type, officer division (e.g. law enforcement operations, detention/correctional operations, etc.), badge number and names associated with the officers involved. If one or more of these fields or dates is unavailable, provide all fields and/or information that is available responsive to my request. If no database or spreadsheet format is available, please provide copies of each individual use of force report or other report where use of force information is documented/reported by officers. Note, this is for all use of force incidents reported by your agency, not limited to only those incidents required to be reported under state or federal programs.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Samuel Sinyangwe

title: Dataset: 911 Call Data (City Of Reno Public Safety Dispatch, Reno, Nv, Usa)

communications.subject: RE: Nevada Public Records Act Request: Dataset: 911 Call Data (City Of Reno Public Safety Dispatch, Reno, Nv, Usa)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Nevada Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

RAW Computer Aided Dispatch Data queried out of your emergency phone system on 911 calls for service from January 2014 to the most recent date data is collected. In CSV, TXT, or XML format, a machine-readable spreadsheet (not XLSX format). 

Here are the column headers which I am requesting:

Master Incident Number or Event Number – Unique numerical identifier of the call for service
Case Number – If an incident report was written, this is the file number, which can be joined to the incidents and arrests datasets
Call Date – Date the call for service was generated
Call Time – Time the call for service was generated
Source – How the call was generated from the public, or self-initiated by an officer
Priority – The priority level of the call response, with ‘P’ being the highest, followed in order numerically
Nature – The description of the call for service.
Address – The block number and street or intersection of the call for service.
Latitude/longitude - coordinates for call of service
X – Mapping coordinate of the call for service
Y – Mapping coordinate of the call for service
District – The patrol district where the call for service was located.
Beat – The patrol beat where the call for service was located, which is a sub-division of the district
Tract – The census tract where the incident occurred, based on 2010 census data
Disposition – How the call for service was closed
Cancelled – Whether the call for service was cancelled prior to officer arrival
Dispatch Date and Time - The exact date and time when the dispatcher sent the call to emergency responders, such as police, fire, or EMS
Entry Date and Time - The date and time when the call was initially logged into the 911 computer-aided dispatch (CAD) system
Received Date and Time - The date and time when the 911 call was first answered by the dispatch center
Enroute Date and Time - The date and time when the assigned responder (e.g., a patrol car, ambulance, or fire truck) began traveling to the incident location
On Scene Date and Time - The date and time when the responder arrived at the scene of the incident
Close Date and Time - The date and time when the incident or call was marked as completed or resolved in the CAD system
Dispatcher ID - A unique identifier for the dispatcher who handled and managed the 911 call. This may be used for tracking or auditing purposes

If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Filed Requests

communications.subject: RE: Nevada Public Records Act Request: Dataset: 911 Call Data (City Of Reno Public Safety Dispatch, Reno, Nv, Usa)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Upon review, additional data fields are necessary to fully interpret the records already requested and/or produced. I therefore request the following additional column headers, to the extent they exist in your CAD system, for the same date range (January 2014 to the most recent date data is collected), in CSV, TXT, or XML format:

* Unique Identifier – A unique numerical identifier for each call for service, if distinct from the master incident or event number
* Dispatcher ID(s) – Identifier(s) for all dispatchers who handled the call, if multiple
* Responder ID – A unique identifier for the responding unit(s) or team(s)
* Prime Unit – Identifier indicating the primary response unit
* Other Units – All additional responding unit identifiers
* Back-up Requested – Indicator or code showing whether back-up was requested
* Transport – Indicator (Y/N) of whether transport occurred
* Transport Start and End Times – If transport occurred
* Transport Destination Address – The address or facility to which transport occurred
* Program or Response Type – Any field identifying non-police, co-response, or alternative response teams (including behavioral health, crisis, or care-based units), if applicable

If any of the above fields are stored under different names, codes, or tables, I request the functional equivalent fields.

I also request any available data dictionary or codebook necessary to interpret these fields.

If you deny any portion of this supplemental request, please cite the specific statutory exemption relied upon and provide the applicable appeal procedures as required by law.

As before, these records are requested for non-commercial purposes and will be made available to the general public. Please inform me in advance of any fees associated with fulfilling this request.

Thank you for your cooperation.

Sincerely,
FR

communications.subject: General Public Records :: G015831-011926
communications.communication:
Dear Filed : 
 
Thank you for your interest in public records of the City of Reno. 
Your request was received in this office on January 19, 2026 and given the reference number: #G015831-011926 for tracking purposes.  Request Details: To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the Nevada Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 

RAW Computer Aided Dispatch Data queried out of your emergency phone system on 911 calls for service from January 2014 to the most recent date data is collected. In CSV, TXT, or XML format, a machine-readable spreadsheet (not XLSX format). 

Here are the column headers which I am requesting: 

Master Incident Number or Event Number – Unique numerical identifier of the call for service 
Case Number – If an incident report was written, this is the file number, which can be joined to the incidents and arrests datasets 
Call Date – Date the call for service was generated 
Call Time – Time the call for service was generated 
Source – How the call was generated from the public, or self-initiated by an officer 
Priority – The priority level of the call response, with ‘P’ being the highest, followed in order numerically 
Nature – The description of the call for service. 
Address – The block number and street or intersection of the call for service. 
Latitude/longitude - coordinates for call of service 
X – Mapping coordinate of the call for service 
Y – Mapping coordinate of the call for service 
District – The patrol district where the call for service was located. 
Beat – The patrol beat where the call for service was located, which is a sub-division of the district 
Tract – The census tract where the incident occurred, based on 2010 census data 
Disposition – How the call for service was closed 
Cancelled – Whether the call for service was cancelled prior to officer arrival 
Dispatch Date and Time - The exact date and time when the dispatcher sent the call to emergency responders, such as police, fire, or EMS 
Entry Date and Time - The date and time when the call was initially logged into the 911 computer-aided dispatch (CAD) system 
Received Date and Time - The date and time when the 911 call was first answered by the dispatch center 
Enroute Date and Time - The date and time when the assigned responder (e.g., a patrol car, ambulance, or fire truck) began traveling to the incident location 
On Scene Date and Time - The date and time when the responder arrived at the scene of the incident 
Close Date and Time - The date and time when the incident or call was marked as completed or resolved in the CAD system 
Dispatcher ID - A unique identifier for the dispatcher who handled and managed the 911 call. This may be used for tracking or auditing purposes 

If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Filed Requests 

Upload documents directly: https://www.muckrock.com/respond/2179797/ 
 
Your request will be forwarded to the appropriate City department(s) to locate the information requested. Pursuant to NRS 239.0107 we will notify you within five (5) business days of receipt of the anticipated date your records will be available, and any estimated cost to produce them. Please note any confidential, proprietary, or protected information will be redacted prior to the release of your records. 
You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you'll receive an email when your request has been completed. 
Again, thank you for using the City of Reno Public Records Center. 
To monitor the progress or update this request please log into the City of Reno Public Records Center. (https://u8387778.ct.sendgrid.net/ls/click?upn=u001.VEsWrlMiJDg0mXafq1mEXS1eZLS95HEK4mFtAPXNsomdAXkYIhnkzBMzWP5FsqSLEsTziUnSqfR0-2Bh9-2BCOAORw-3D-3DRgKQ_Az7K-2BgFXAgJb2GL2dtVthKak7grycJznPTBDzUReg-2BvpYb9HC-2BCVrTOYbRbheXkBNhF-2BWky1FHxX8w8dHBgaBjgMuBNt7Ke0A-2BXkzmkM9Lwq3JTh08pgYBvYODy7QXg-2FKkK6YF-2BkUJa-2BADqaTnLy9jMoXdkYInzL9NKPdfDcut4HNEj4Hz81Btuih6x8k4IJ39RL9gaZxEmWs-2BC2vB2aPXptGnznaqzQ1yeTP9TeQIE-3D)

The result of your public records request is available on the City of Reno Public Records Center. Please click on the link below to access your records: General Public Records - G015831-011926  *Please note that portions of your request have been redacted for the following reasons: 
Dispatch Logs retained to the minimum period of two (2) calendar years from the date of the dispatch (NRS 11.190 (4)(e), NRS 707.500, NRS 239B.030)

Thank you for contacting the City of Reno. 
Sincerely, 
Records Division 
City Clerk's Office Please note any confidential, proprietary, or protected information will be redacted prior to the release of the records. There could be a charge for copies of public records. If the estimated cost of the copies requested is $25.00 or more, the requester will be required to pay in full prior to reproduction. Materials will be held for 14 days. If not retrieved, the requester will be charged in full for a second reproduction in addition to any unpaid original charges. Advance payment will be forfeited if material is not retrieved.

Pursuant to the New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 

I am requesting all records related to the arrests of Elijah Ray Chavez on 
9/1/24 near 2125 S ESPINA ST, Dona Ana, NM,

by the Las Cruces Police Department (LCPD), NMSU Police, and DASO.

Upload documents directly: https://www.muckrock.com/respond/2143405/ 
The purpose of this message is to provide you with a notification relating to the Inspection of Public Records Act (hereinafter “IPRA”) request you provided the City of Las Cruces (hereinafter “City” or “Las Cruces”). Under NMSA 1978, § 14-2-8, the City has determined that it does not have possession of and/or responsibility for the 911 call audio and transcripts, CAD logs, radio traffic, or any other dispatch records that you have requested.  However, the City knows the proper custodian of these records to be Mesilla Valley Regional Dispatch Authority (MVRDA), 911 Lake Tahoe Ct., Las Cruces, NM, 88007, (575) 526-0795, https://www.mvrda.org/records-request-instructions/.  As such, on December 1, 2025, the City forwarded your request to MVRDA.  To expedite your request, you may consider submitting an additional records request to that agency's records custodian directly.  In light of this notification, the City considers the request for dispatch records closed.  New Mexico Statutes Annotated (hereinafter “NMSA”) 1978, § 14-2-8(C) states, in pertinent part, that a “written request . . .shall identify the records sought with reasonable particularity.” The purpose of this requirement is to provide governmental agencies with the information necessary to accurately and fully respond to public record requests. Upon review, the City has determined that your request, as currently written, is too broad to process effectively. In order to facilitate a thorough and accurate response, the City will separate each case referenced in your request into individual requests. This approach allows us to address each case independently and ensures a more efficient and complete response. 

Accordingly, this request is now closed. Please refer to the respective requests for each case moving forward. Sincerely, 
Christine Rivera 
Records Custodian 
(575) 541-2112

communications.subject: [Document Released to Requester] MVRDA public records request #25-248
communications.communication:
MVRDA ************************************************************************ Documents have been released for record request #25-248 along with the following message: The Mesilla Valley Regional Dispatch Authority (MVRDA) received your public records request on December 1, 2025 to inspect certain records. After reviewing your request, conducting a search and review of responsive records, we have located: one (1) CAD report and one (1) audio file. A portion of responsive record(s) has been redacted due to protected information exempt that is exempt from disclosure pursuant to: NM Stat §14-2-1.1 for personal identifier information. Responsive records have been released to you. Please see the list below for additional details on no records found for specific incidents/additional information needed: * 9/1/24 near 2125 S ESPINA ST, Dona Ana, NM, (No records found) * 1/9/25 near 2306 S ESPINA ST D11, Dona Ana, NM (No records found) * 4/10/25 near E UNIVERSITY AVE/LOCUST, Dona Ana, NM, (Multiple incidents for this day and location. Please provide an approximate time.) * 7/9/25 near 1410 S SOLANO, Dona Ana, NM, (No records found) * 8/9/25 near 2306 S ESPINA #11, Dona Ana, NM and (No records found) * 9/5/2025 near EPDC ANNEX, Dona Ana, NM by the Las Cruces Police Department (LCPD), NMSU Police, and DASO. (No records found) MVRDA considers your request complete. * LCPD2025086829CAD_Redacted.pdf * LCPD2025086829.zip Document links are valid for one month. After January 3, you will need to sign in to view the document(s). ************************************************************************ Questions about your request? Reply to this email or sign in to contact staff at MVRDA.

Technical support: See our help page

More specifically, the City has determined that it requires an additional reasonable period of time to gather, review, and appropriately redact any and all public records associated with your request. 

The City is still currently in the process of gathering, reviewing, and appropriately redacting the public records associated with your request. communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
RE: Police Records Request, Reference # P005228-120125 Dear Beyonce Salvador, The City of Las Cruces received the following public records request from you on December 01, 2025: Original Request P005183-113025 

I am requesting all records related to the arrests of Elijah Ray Chavez on 
7/9/25 near 1410 S SOLANO, Dona Ana, NM, 

I am specifically requesting: 

The complete incident and arrest reports, including officer narratives and any probable cause affidavits 

Any body-worn camera (BWC) footage from responding officers 

Any 911 call audio and transcripts 

CAD logs, dispatch records, or radio traffic related to the incident 

Any photographs, witness statements, or scene documentation 

This request is made in the public interest to promote transparency in domestic incident responses and the handling of battery cases involving household members. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Beyonce Salvador 
The purpose of this message is to provide you with a partial response to the Inspection of Public Records Act (hereinafter “IPRA”) request you provided the City of Las Cruces (hereinafter “City” or “Las Cruces”). The City has gathered, reviewed, and appropriately redacted the following public records associated with your request: 

Nine (9) documents 
 
  *  New Mexico Statutes Annotated (hereinafter “NMSA”) Section 14-2-1.1 states “Protected personal identifier information contained in public records may be redacted by a public body before inspection or copying of a record.” The term “protected personal identifier information” is defined within NMSA Section 14-2-6(F) to include:  (1) all but the last four digits of a: (a) taxpayer identification number;  (b) financial account number; (c) credit or debit card number; or (d) driver’s license number;  (2) all but the year of a person’s date of birth; (3) a social security number; and (4) with regard to a nonelected employee of a public body in the context of the person’s employment, the employee’s nonbusiness home street address, but not the city, state or zip code;  therefore, any of the above-described “protected personal identifier information” found within the responsive records have been redacted. New Mexico Statutes Annotated (hereinafter “NMSA”) Section 14-2-1(N) states “[e]very person has a right to inspect public records except as otherwise provided by law.” NMSA Section 31-26-4(A) states that “A victim shall have the right to be treated with fairness and respect for the victim's dignity and privacy throughout the criminal justice process.” The term “Victim” is defined within NMSA 31-26-3(F) to mean “an individual against whom a criminal offense is committed. "Victim" also means a family member or a victim's representative when the individual against whom a criminal offense was committed is a minor, is incompetent or is a homicide victim. The term “criminal offense” is defined within NMSA 31-26-3(F) to include twenty-one (21) specific crimes. Therefore, any personal information associated within Victim(s) as defined by the Victim’s Rights Act have been redacted. A download link with the contents of this request has been e-mailed to you from AXON.  This download link expires in three (3) days. Please contact our office by replying to this email or via telephone if you have any issues accessing the documents or if you wish to receive the documents in another format. Pursuant to NMSA 1978, § 14-2-10, the City has determined that your written request is excessively burdensome and/or broad. More specifically, the City has determined that it requires an additional reasonable period of time to gather, review, and appropriately redact any and all public records associated with your request.  Although the City cannot anticipate when the remainder of the responsive records associated with your request will become available, the City will produce them within a reasonable period of time. Due to a high volume of requests, the City will be providing rolling disclosures associated with this request. Further, the City will provide a written status update regarding your request within thirty (30) days. While the City may be able to process a portion of your request before that time, we are not guaranteeing this result. We appreciate your patience and understanding in this matter. 

Christine Rivera, Records Custodian, is the official responsible for any redactions and/or denial of your request. Thank you for your attention to this matter. Should you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to contact my office. Sincerely, 
Christine Rivera 
Records Custodian 
(575) 541-2112
